fullDescription.text: qs before 6.10.3, as used in Express before 4.17.3 and other products, allows attackers to cause a Node process hang for an Express application because an __ proto__ key can be used. In many typical Express use cases, an unauthenticated remote attacker can place the attack payload in the query string of the URL that is used to visit the application, such as a[__proto__]=b&a[__proto__]&a[length]=100000000. The fix was backported to qs 6.9.7, 6.8.3, 6.7.3, 6.6.1, 6.5.3, 6.4.1, 6.3.3, and 6.2.4 (and therefore Express 4.17.3, which has "deps: qs@6.9.7" in its release description, is not vulnerable).

## Description
qs before 6.10.3, as used in Express before 4.17.3 and other products, allows attackers to cause a Node process hang for an Express application because an __ proto__ key can be used. In many typical Express use cases, an unauthenticated remote attacker can place the attack payload in the query string of the URL that is used to visit the application, such as a[__proto__]=b&a[__proto__]&a[length]=100000000. The fix was backported to qs 6.9.7, 6.8.3, 6.7.3, 6.6.1, 6.5.3, 6.4.1, 6.3.3, and 6.2.4 (and therefore Express 4.17.3, which has "deps: qs@6.9.7" in its release description, is not vulnerable).

## Description
moment is vulnerable to path traversal which may lead to the modification of sensitive information within a file directory on the file system. An attacker can exploit this flaw by manipulating directory pathways using unwanted characters to access and modify a resource that is outside the intended directory.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [CVE-2022-24785](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2022-24785) - Directory Traversal



## Solution
Fixed in version [**2.29.2**](https://github.com/moment/moment/releases/tag/2.29.2) by [this](https://github.com/moment/moment/commit/4211bfc8f15746be4019bba557e29a7ba83d54c5) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/moment/moment/tags).

## Workaround
The vendor has stated [here](https://github.com/moment/moment/security/advisories/GHSA-8hfj-j24r-96c4) the following workaround:

"Sanitize user-provided locale name before passing it to moment.js".

fullDescription.text:
Moment.js is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issue due to an inefficient regular expression in use within the `rfc2822` parsing code.

An attacker could submit a crafted input containing more that 10,000 characters in order to trigger an excessive consumption of resources that result in a slowdown of processing.

help.markdown:
## Upgrade Guidance



| **Affected Dependency**  | **Recommended short term version** | **Recommended long term version** |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| moment 2.24.0  | 2.29.4  | 2.29.4 |


[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/components/1157712a-4c47-4ed6-9dd3-d9810f50e09b?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&component=a354cb9d-37ad-4138-b5c8-ff9d89112618)


## Description
Moment.js is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issue due to an inefficient regular expression in use within the `rfc2822` parsing code.

An attacker could submit a crafted input containing more that 10,000 characters in order to trigger an excessive consumption of resources that result in a slowdown of processing.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [CVE-2022-31129](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2022-31129) - Incorrect Regular Expression



## Solution
Fixed in [**2.29.4**](https://github.com/moment/moment/releases/tag/2.29.4) by [this](https://github.com/moment/moment/commit/9a3b5894f3d5d602948ac8a02e4ee528a49ca3a3) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/moment).

**Note**: The vendor has stated in their [advisory](https://github.com/moment/moment/security/advisories/GHSA-wc69-rhjr-hc9g) that the patch for **2.29.4** can be applied to all affected versions with minimal tweaking.

## Workaround
The vendor has suggested [here](https://github.com/moment/moment/security/advisories/GHSA-wc69-rhjr-hc9g) that users of Moment.js who pass a user-supplied string to a constructor should apply input length filters to help with this issue, and other potential future regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issues.

fullDescription.text:
minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

fullDescription.text:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

Node.js Hawk contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources and cause a crash.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hawk).

The vendor has issued the following workaround:

"`Hawk.authenticate()` accepts the options argument. If that contains host and port, those would be used instead of a call to `utils.parseHost()`".

## Description
The handlebars package for Node.js is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to improper restrictions on object access in templates which can lead to prototype pollution. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying maliciously crafted input.

fullDescription.text: undefsafe is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient restrictions being placed on object modification functionality. An attacker that is able to control the input to the `undefsafe()` function could leverage that function to modify the prototype of an object. The exact impact that the attacker can achieve will depend on how the object is used, but could potentially include cross-site scripting (XSS) and remote code execution (RCE).

## Description
undefsafe is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient restrictions being placed on object modification functionality. An attacker that is able to control the input to the `undefsafe()` function could leverage that function to modify the prototype of an object. The exact impact that the attacker can achieve will depend on how the object is used, but could potentially include cross-site scripting (XSS) and remote code execution (RCE).

## Description
The braces package for Node.js contains a bad regular expression that causes catastrophic back tracking. If an application is supplying untrusted input to this module, it is possible for an attacker to input a string that will cause the application to hang or possibly crash due to resource exhaustion. This is better known as a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:large_blue_circle: [CVE-2018-1109](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2018-1109) - Incorrect Regular Expression

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/micromatch/braces/releases).

## Description
Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [CVE-2023-28155](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2023-28155) - Server-Side Request Forgery





## Workaround
A patch has been proposed [here](https://github.com/request/request/pull/3444/commits/d42332182512e56ba68446f49c3e3711e04301a2) that has not been merged with the upstream repository yet.

help.text: Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or cause remote code execution or a denial-of-service (*DoS*).

fullDescription.text:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

fullDescription.text:
Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).

fullDescription.text:
minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

fullDescription.text:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

## Description
An open redirect vulnerability has been discovered in Got due to the insufficient validation of URLs. An attacker could exploit this by tricking a user into clicking a malicious link that may be controlled by an attacker.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:large_blue_circle: [CVE-2022-33987](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2022-33987) - Open URL Redirect



## Solution
Fixed in versions [**12.1.0**](https://github.com/sindresorhus/got/releases/tag/v12.1.0) by [this](https://github.com/sindresorhus/got/commit/861ccd9ac2237df762a9e2beed7edd88c60782dc) commit, and in [**11.8.5**](https://github.com/sindresorhus/got/releases/tag/v11.8.5) by [this](https://github.com/sindresorhus/got/commit/bce8ce7d528a675bd5a8d996e110b73674e290d2) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/sindresorhus/got/releases).



## Dependency tree
- owasp-nodejs-goat/1.3.0/-npm
    - nodemon/1.19.1
        - update-notifier/2.5.0
            - latest-version/3.1.0
                - package-json/4.0.1
                    - got/6.7.1

fullDescription.text: nconf is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient input validation within the memory engine. This could allow an attacker to maliciously modify object prototypes, which depending on how objects are used by an application, could cause impacts such as denial-of-service (DoS), cross-site scripting (XSS) or remote code execution (RCE).

## Description
nconf is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient input validation within the memory engine. This could allow an attacker to maliciously modify object prototypes, which depending on how objects are used by an application, could cause impacts such as denial-of-service (DoS), cross-site scripting (XSS) or remote code execution (RCE).

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [CVE-2022-21803](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2022-21803) - Weak Input Validation



## Solution
Fixed in version [**0.11.4**](https://github.com/indexzero/nconf/releases/tag/v0.11.4) by [this](https://github.com/indexzero/nconf/commit/feaba562b812b21215897f71b0c8b3bf39cf8d7d) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/indexzero/nconf/releases).

## Description
qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (*DoS*) due to improper validation of user-supplied input. This could allow an attacker to render services unavailable or potentially craft other attacks.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [CVE-2017-1000048](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2017-1000048) - Weak Input Validation



## Solution
Fixed by [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/760d0a13912f788893b55d8f295dd47520b9d397) commit and [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/1c045cac47718c1c18c08df770ca0451e66e4e62) commit in:
* **[6.4.0](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.4.0)**
* **[6.3.2](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.3.2)**
* **[6.2.3](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.2.3)**
* **[6.1.2](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.1.2)**
* **[6.0.4](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.0.4)**

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases).

Note: initially the vendor partially fixed this issue with [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/beade029171b8cef9cee0d03ebe577e2dd84976d) commit, before it was discovered that this still allowed an attacker to exploit the issue using a prefixed `[` character, thus the above further commits were required.

fullDescription.text:
minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

fullDescription.text:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

fullDescription.text:
set-value is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient input validation.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to modify the Object prototype properties which causes additional properties or changes to the objects which could result in denial-of-service (DoS) or alter the integrity of the application. If the application uses polluted objects in conjunction with code execution primitives (such as eval), it may be possible for an attacker to execute malicious code.

It was later determined that this issue could be bypassed via a type confusion vulnerability as noted in **CVE-2021-23440** (**BDSA-2021-2911**).

fullDescription.text:
fsevents npm package is vulnerable to hijacking due to malicious code run during installation via a hijacked URL in the install configuration. This would allow the current owner of the URL to run code of their choosing on each installation of the package.

**Note:** Originally, the credentials to the S3 bucket of the affected URL were [lost](https://github.com/fsevents/fsevents/releases/tag/v1.2.11). It was demonstrated by a security researcher that the bucket became available to register once again, and it was taken over by the researcher to demonstrate possible impact of this vulnerability. At this time, AWS has taken possession of the S3 bucket and currently blocks all access, neutralizing any threat. Should this bucket become available to use in the future, affected versions of fsevents will once again become vulnerable. This occurred in August 2023, when the bucket was briefly reinstated in error.

## Description
Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via insufficient absolute path sanitization.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)

## Solution
Fixed in:

* [**4.4.14**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.14) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/efc6bb0dbd54df8c7285d7aac12bba959b8387a6)commit. 
* [**5.0.6**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.6) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/69c56cb5aeb61941f5ab40dcbc7b47c181ec499a) commit. 
* [**6.1.1**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.1) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/1f036ca23f64a547bdd6c79c1a44bc62e8115da4) commit.

fullDescription.text:
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

## Description
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [CVE-2021-32803](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2021-32803) - Weak Input Validation



## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**3.2.3**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v3.2.3) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/85d3a942b4064e4ff171f91696fced7975167349) commit,
* [**4.4.15**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.15) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/46fe35083e2676e31c4e0a81639dce6da7aaa356) commit, 
* [**5.0.7**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.7) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/5987d9a41f6bfbf1ddab1098e1fdcf1a5618f571) commit, 
* [**6.1.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/9dbdeb6df8e9dbd96fa9e84341b9d74734be6c20) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases).

## Workaround
It is suggested on [npmjs.com](https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1771#workarounds) that it is possible to mitigate the vulnerability by creating a custom `onentry` method which sanitizes the `entry.path` or a `filter` method which removes entries with absolute paths.

## Description
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [CVE-2021-37701](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2021-37701) - Directory Traversal



## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**4.4.16**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.16) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/3f2e2da3866c4e5f26ca0c0d6721cb371c5a3933) commit. 
* [**5.0.8**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.8) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/ab3e9036dc4504413fb6f154ea6943af5c187e26)commit. 
* [**6.1.7**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.7) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/53602669f58ddbeb3294d7196b3320aaaed22728) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/tags).

## Workaround
Users can workaround this vulnerability by creating a custom filter method (`x` in this example) which prevents all symbolic links from being extracted:

```
const tar = require('tar')

tar.x({
  file: 'archive.tgz',
  filter: (file, entry) => {
    if (entry.type === 'SymbolicLink') {
      return false
    } else {
      return true
    }
  }
})
```

fullDescription.text: The Node.js `ws` module contains a flaw when handling headers containing the Object.prototype property. If successful, a denial-of-service (*DoS*) will occur.

## Description
The Node.js `ws` module contains a flaw when handling headers containing the Object.prototype property. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a specially crafted Sec-WebSocket-Extensions header containing the vulnerable property name as an extension or parameter. If successful, a denial-of-service (*DoS*) will occur.

## Description
Selenium Grid is vulnerable to stored cross-site scripting (XSS) due to the insufficient sanitization of user input. This allows attackers to execute arbitrary web scripts in a victim's browser via a crafted payload. This could allow the attacker to steal information from a victim, such as browser cookies, or to manipulate the contents of the web page.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2020-4845](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2020-4845) - Cross-site Scripting



## Solution
The vendor states [here](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/8259#issuecomment-632920668) that:
* Grid **3.x** is deprecated and not under development anymore.
* Grid **4** will have a different UI.

## Description
Selenium contains a remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability. An unprivileged attacker could exploit this by using the config file to set a custom handler. This may lead to the execution of remote code.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2021-4248](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-4248) - Third-party component usage



## Solution
The Selenium `Grid4` Documentation has been updated [here](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/seleniumhq.github.io/commit/ef4a424c3a6a52b94f62b397baf84f7707ca6160) which warns users about not leaving a Grid exposed. 

A recommendation has also been included [here](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/issues/9526) to use `basic auth` to help mitigate the risk and protect Grids. The following commits introduce and reference this functionality in Selenium version [**4.0.0-rc-1**](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/releases/tag/selenium-4.0.0-rc-1):
* [Commit 1](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/63fd7f722d36dd4942a574c8569a4b2ec4849e2f).
* [Commit 2](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/53ad48fbf4349413356d5a9a9589288ca6ed1d7a).
* [Commit 3](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/39b35f886ffdad505e29ae9ec6082c706a735d85).
* [Commit 4](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/commit/2c437713b336ca516aca2666da672500fb862c36).

The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via insufficient absolute path sanitization.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)

fullDescription.text:
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

## Description
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [CVE-2021-32803](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2021-32803) - Weak Input Validation



## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**3.2.3**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v3.2.3) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/85d3a942b4064e4ff171f91696fced7975167349) commit,
* [**4.4.15**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.15) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/46fe35083e2676e31c4e0a81639dce6da7aaa356) commit, 
* [**5.0.7**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.7) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/5987d9a41f6bfbf1ddab1098e1fdcf1a5618f571) commit, 
* [**6.1.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/9dbdeb6df8e9dbd96fa9e84341b9d74734be6c20) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases).

## Workaround
It is suggested on [npmjs.com](https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1771#workarounds) that it is possible to mitigate the vulnerability by creating a custom `onentry` method which sanitizes the `entry.path` or a `filter` method which removes entries with absolute paths.

## Description
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [CVE-2021-37701](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2021-37701) - Directory Traversal



## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**4.4.16**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.16) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/3f2e2da3866c4e5f26ca0c0d6721cb371c5a3933) commit. 
* [**5.0.8**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.8) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/ab3e9036dc4504413fb6f154ea6943af5c187e26)commit. 
* [**6.1.7**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.7) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/53602669f58ddbeb3294d7196b3320aaaed22728) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/tags).

## Workaround
Users can workaround this vulnerability by creating a custom filter method (`x` in this example) which prevents all symbolic links from being extracted:

```
const tar = require('tar')

tar.x({
  file: 'archive.tgz',
  filter: (file, entry) => {
    if (entry.type === 'SymbolicLink') {
      return false
    } else {
      return true
    }
  }
})
```

fullDescription.text:
Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) as the user-controllable input to certain functions is not sufficiently checked, allowing an attacker to add or modify existing properties of presumably immutable `Object` data structure. An unauthenticated attacker can leverage this flaw to add arbitrary properties to objects used by the web application which can be leveraged to cause a crash or to prevent the server from responding to all requests.

This vulnerability may also lead to remote code execution (RCE) in some applications, depending on the implementation.

fullDescription.text:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

fullDescription.text:
Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).

fullDescription.text:
The uglify-js package is vulnerable to a denial-of-service condition due to CPU consumption when parsing a certain types of input. This can cause an application running the uglify-js package to hang by blocking the event loop. 

An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying crafted input to the `parse()` function call.

help.markdown:
## Upgrade Guidance



| **Affected Dependency**  | **Recommended short term version** | **Recommended long term version** |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| uglify-js 2.4.24  | 2.8.29  | 3.17.4 |


[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/components/ec69e354-1c43-4365-b6d4-e1c66ccbe5e1?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&component=68fb2c7c-4a59-4944-8b90-c8454b81bc5f)


## Description
The uglify-js package is vulnerable to a denial-of-service condition due to CPU consumption when parsing a certain types of input. This can cause an application running the uglify-js package to hang by blocking the event loop. 

An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying crafted input to the `parse()` function call.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [CVE-2015-8858](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2015-8858) - Third-party component usage



## Solution
Fixed in version [**2.6.0**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/uglify-js).

Fixed under Debian package via experimental repository in version [**3.3.10-1**](https://wiki.debian.org/DebianExperimental).

Note: Experimental is a staging/collaboration/experimental area for development and is not fit for production.

    - swig/1.4.2
        - uglify-js/2.4.24

fullDescription.text:
Babel Travserse is vulnerable to an arbitrary code execution issue due to how the `_evaluate()` function allows for the evaluation of inherited methods. This affects plugins that rely on the `path.evaluate()` or `path.evaluateTruthy()` internal Babel methods.

In cases where Babel is used to compile untrusted code, an attacker could potentially submit specially crafted code that, during compilation, could be evaluated and executed during the compilation process.

help.markdown:
## Upgrade Guidance



| **Affected Dependency**  | **Recommended short term version** | **Recommended long term version** |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| babel-traverse 6.11.4  | 6.26.0  | 6.26.0 |


[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/components/7404df0f-dae0-48f5-a40b-5972b7a935eb?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&component=bd2652a3-74ea-44a9-8889-f3e98aa4dfa0)


## Description
Babel Travserse is vulnerable to an arbitrary code execution issue due to how the `_evaluate()` function allows for the evaluation of inherited methods. This affects plugins that rely on the `path.evaluate()` or `path.evaluateTruthy()` internal Babel methods.

In cases where Babel is used to compile untrusted code, an attacker could potentially submit specially crafted code that, during compilation, could be evaluated and executed during the compilation process.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2023-2769](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2023-2769) - Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs



## Solution
Fixed in [**8.0.0-alpha4**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@babel/traverse/v/8.0.0-alpha.4) and [**7.23.2**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@babel/traverse/v/7.23.2) by [this](https://github.com/babel/babel/commit/b13376b346946e3f62fc0848c1d2a23223314c82) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@babel/traverse).

## Workaround
The vendor has provided the following workaround suggestion in their [advisory](https://github.com/babel/babel/security/advisories/GHSA-67hx-6x53-jw92):
> If you cannot upgrade `@babel/traverse` and are using one of the affected packages, upgrade them to their latest version to avoid triggering the vulnerable code path in affected `@babel/traverse` versions:
> 
>     @babel/plugin-transform-runtime v7.23.2
>     @babel/preset-env v7.23.2
>     @babel/helper-define-polyfill-provider v0.4.3
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-corejs2 v0.4.6
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-corejs3 v0.8.5
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-es-shims v0.10.0
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-regenerator v0.5.3

## Dependency tree
- owasp-nodejs-goat/1.3.0/-npm
    - grunt-if/0.2.0
        - grunt-contrib-nodeunit/1.0.0
            - nodeunit/0.9.5
                - tap/7.1.2
                    - nyc/7.1.0
                        - istanbul-lib-instrument/1.1.0-alpha.4
                            - babel-traverse/6.11.4


## References
* Common Weakness Enumeration: [CWE-184](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/184.html)
* Common Weakness Enumeration: [CWE-20](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/20.html)

## Description
qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.

fullDescription.text: Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

## Description
Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [CVE-2023-28155](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2023-28155) - Server-Side Request Forgery





## Workaround
A patch has been proposed [here](https://github.com/request/request/pull/3444/commits/d42332182512e56ba68446f49c3e3711e04301a2) that has not been merged with the upstream repository yet.

## Dependency tree

        - retire/1.1.6
            - request/2.79.0

## Description
The randomatic module for Node.js generates random values using a cryptographically weak psuedo-random number generator. This might produce predictable values rather than random ones making it possible for an attacker to exploit this vulnerability via brute forcing.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [CVE-2017-16028](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2017-16028) - Insecure Pseudo-Random Number Generator Used



## Solution

This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

## Description
Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

fullDescription.text:
set-value is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient input validation.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to modify the Object prototype properties which causes additional properties or changes to the objects which could result in denial-of-service (DoS) or alter the integrity of the application. If the application uses polluted objects in conjunction with code execution primitives (such as eval), it may be possible for an attacker to execute malicious code.

It was later determined that this issue could be bypassed via a type confusion vulnerability as noted in **CVE-2021-23440** (**BDSA-2021-2911**).

## Description
Mixin-deep is vulnerable to prototype pollution attack. This could allow an attacker to manipulate a function to add or modify properties of `Object.prototype` via a constructor payload. Successfully exploiting results in a denial-of-service (DoS) and code execution may be possible.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [CVE-2019-10746](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2019-10746) - Sensitive Data Exposure



## Solution
Fixed in:

* **[1.3.2](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/releases/tag/1.3.2)** by [this](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/commit/90ee1fab375fccfd9b926df718243339b4976d50) commit.
* **[2.0.1](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/releases/tag/2.0.1)** by [this](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/commit/8f464c8ce9761a8c9c2b3457eaeee9d404fa7af9) commit.

## Workaround
1. Freeze the prototype use Object.freeze (Object.prototype).
2. Require schema validation of JSON input.
3. Avoid using unsafe recursive merge functions.
4. Consider using objects without prototypes (for example, Object.create(null)), breaking the prototype chain and preventing pollution.
5. As a best practice use Map instead of Object.

minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

fullDescription.text:
ShellJS is vulnerable to privilege escalation and denial-of-service (DoS) issues due to how file permissions used by the internal implementation of `shell.exec()` are mishandled.

If ShellJS scripts running locally are using the ShellJS `exec()` function, an attacker with low-level privileges on the system could abuse the flaw in order to leak sensitive information, such as passwords, in order to perform local privilege escalation or shutdown privileged ShellJS processes.

A vendor comment [here](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/issues/1058#issuecomment-1008657537) indicates that this issue only impacts the `synchronous` version of `shell.exec()`. All other ShellJS methods (including the `async` usage of `shell.exec()`) should not be impacted.

fullDescription.text:
ShellJS is vulnerable to information disclosure due to the unsafe handling of the `stdout` and `stderr` streams of the `shell.exec()` function. A local attacker could potentially obtain sensitive data that has been produced by processes by examining the `stdout` file that is produced by ShellJS. This vulnerability can also be leveraged to crash privileged ShellJS processes.

It should be noted that only the synchronous version of `shell.exec()` function is affected by this issue.

fullDescription.text:
Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) as the user-controllable input to certain functions is not sufficiently checked, allowing an attacker to add or modify existing properties of presumably immutable `Object` data structure. An unauthenticated attacker can leverage this flaw to add arbitrary properties to objects used by the web application which can be leveraged to cause a crash or to prevent the server from responding to all requests.

This vulnerability may also lead to remote code execution (RCE) in some applications, depending on the implementation.

fullDescription.text:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

help.text:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

fullDescription.text:
Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).

## Description
The stringstream package for Node.js is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.  If an application is supplying untrusted user input to the `write` function, an attacker can trigger an out-of-bounds read that may result in uninitilzed memory being exposed of the application crashing.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [CVE-2018-21270](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2018-21270) - Classic Buffer Overflow



## Solution
Fixed in [**0.0.6**](https://github.com/mhart/StringStream/releases/tag/v0.0.6) by [this](https://github.com/mhart/StringStream/commit/afbc7442220358419e330618e47f3a65fc265b1b) commit.



## Dependency tree
- owasp-nodejs-goat/1.3.0/-npm
    - grunt-npm-install/0.3.1
        - npm/3.10.10
            - request/2.75.0
                - stringstream/0.0.5


## References
* Common Weakness Enumeration: [CWE-120](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/120.html)

If an application is supplying untrusted user input to the `write` function, an attacker can trigger an out-of-bounds read that may result in uninitilzed memory being exposed of the application crashing.

fullDescription.text: Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

help.markdown:

## Description
Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:yellow_circle: [CVE-2023-28155](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/CVE-2023-28155) - Server-Side Request Forgery





## Workaround
A patch has been proposed [here](https://github.com/request/request/pull/3444/commits/d42332182512e56ba68446f49c3e3711e04301a2) that has not been merged with the upstream repository yet.

        - request/2.36.0

shortDescription.text: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere

fullDescription.text: The `sandbox` attribute of an `iframe` is not set in HTML. This iframe loads content from a third-party site. If the JavaScript in that iframe is malicious or was compromised, an attacker can break out of the iframe, access the DOM of the main page, and mount a clickjacking or a phishing attack.

help.markdown:
## Description
The `sandbox` attribute of an `iframe` is not set in HTML. This iframe loads content from a third-party site. If the JavaScript in that iframe is malicious or was compromised, an attacker can break out of the iframe, access the DOM of the main page, and mount a clickjacking or a phishing attack.

[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/issues?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&filter=issueType%3Alocalized-name%3DInclusion%20of%20Functionality%20from%20Untrusted%20Control%20Sphere%26context%3AtoolType%3Dsast)



## Remediation
Potential mitigations include the following:
  1. Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.
  2. When the set of acceptable objects, such as filenames or URLs, is limited or known, create a mapping from a set of fixed input values (such as numeric IDs) to the actual filenames or URLs, and reject all other inputs.

For example, ID 1 could map to "inbox.txt" and ID 2 could map to "profile.txt". Features such as the ESAPI AccessReferenceMap [REF-45] provide this capability.

  3. For any security checks that are performed on the client side, ensure that these checks are duplicated on the server side, in order to avoid CWE-602. Attackers can bypass the client-side checks by modifying values after the checks have been performed, or by changing the client to remove the client-side checks entirely. Then, these modified values would be submitted to the server.
  4. Run the code in a "jail" or similar sandbox environment that enforces strict boundaries between the process and the operating system. This may effectively restrict which files can be accessed in a particular directory or which commands can be executed by the software.

OS-level examples include the Unix chroot jail, AppArmor, and SELinux. In general, managed code may provide some protection. For example, java.io.FilePermission in the Java SecurityManager allows the software to specify restrictions on file operations.

This may not be a feasible solution, and it only limits the impact to the operating system; the rest of the application may still be subject to compromise.

Be careful to avoid CWE-243 and other weaknesses related to jails.

  5. Run your code using the lowest privileges that are required to accomplish the necessary tasks [REF-76]. If possible, create isolated accounts with limited privileges that are only used for a single task. That way, a successful attack will not immediately give the attacker access to the rest of the software or its environment. For example, database applications rarely need to run as the database administrator, especially in day-to-day operations.
  6. Assume all input is malicious. Use an "accept known good" input validation strategy, i.e., use a list of acceptable inputs that strictly conform to specifications. Reject any input that does not strictly conform to specifications, or transform it into something that does.

When performing input validation, consider all potentially relevant properties, including length, type of input, the full range of acceptable values, missing or extra inputs, syntax, consistency across related fields, and conformance to business rules. As an example of business rule logic, "boat" may be syntactically valid because it only contains alphanumeric characters, but it is not valid if the input is only expected to contain colors such as "red" or "blue."

Do not rely exclusively on looking for malicious or malformed inputs. This is likely to miss at least one undesirable input, especially if the code's environment changes. This can give attackers enough room to bypass the intended validation. However, denylists can be useful for detecting potential attacks or determining which inputs are so malformed that they should be rejected outright.

When validating filenames, use stringent allowlists that limit the character set to be used. If feasible, only allow a single "." character in the filename to avoid weaknesses such as CWE-23, and exclude directory separators such as "/" to avoid CWE-36. Use a list of allowable file extensions, which will help to avoid CWE-434.

Do not rely exclusively on a filtering mechanism that removes potentially dangerous characters. This is equivalent to a denylist, which may be incomplete (CWE-184). For example, filtering "/" is insufficient protection if the filesystem also supports the use of "\" as a directory separator. Another possible error could occur when the filtering is applied in a way that still produces dangerous data (CWE-182). For example, if "../" sequences are removed from the ".../...//" string in a sequential fashion, two instances of "../" would be removed from the original string, but the remaining characters would still form the "../" string.

  7. Store library, include, and utility files outside of the web document root, if possible. Otherwise, store them in a separate directory and use the web server's access control capabilities to prevent attackers from directly requesting them. One common practice is to define a fixed constant in each calling program, then check for the existence of the constant in the library/include file; if the constant does not exist, then the file was directly requested, and it can exit immediately.

This significantly reduces the chance of an attacker being able to bypass any protection mechanisms that are in the base program but not in the include files. It will also reduce the attack surface.

  8. Understand all the potential areas where untrusted inputs can enter your software: parameters or arguments, cookies, anything read from the network, environment variables, reverse DNS lookups, query results, request headers, URL components, e-mail, files, filenames, databases, and any external systems that provide data to the application. Remember that such inputs may be obtained indirectly through API calls.

Many file inclusion problems occur because the programmer assumed that certain inputs could not be modified, especially for cookies and URL components.

  9. Use an application firewall that can detect attacks against this weakness. It can be beneficial in cases in which the code cannot be fixed (because it is controlled by a third party), as an emergency prevention measure while more comprehensive software assurance measures are applied, or to provide defense in depth.

## References
* Common Weakness Enumeration: [CWE-829](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/829.html)
help.text: The `sandbox` attribute of an `iframe` is not set in HTML. This iframe loads content from a third-party site. If the JavaScript in that iframe is malicious or was compromised, an attacker can break out of the iframe, access the DOM of the main page, and mount a clickjacking or a phishing attack.

fullDescription.text: The Docker container is not configured to drop all default capabilities and then add only required one. Thus the container may be granted excessive privileges which violate the least privilege principle.

help.markdown:
## Description
The Docker container is not configured to drop all default capabilities and then add only required one. Thus the container may be granted excessive privileges which violate the least privilege principle.

[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/issues?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&filter=issueType%3Alocalized-name%3DImproper%20Access%20Control%26context%3AtoolType%3Dsast)



## Remediation
Potential mitigations include the following:
  1. Very carefully manage the setting, management, and handling of privileges. Explicitly manage trust zones in the software.
  2. Compartmentalize the system to have "safe" areas where trust boundaries can be unambiguously drawn. Do not allow sensitive data to go outside of the trust boundary and always be careful when interfacing with a compartment outside of the safe area.

Ensure that appropriate compartmentalization is built into the system design, and the compartmentalization allows for and reinforces privilege separation functionality. Architects and designers should rely on the principle of least privilege to decide the appropriate time to use privileges and the time to drop privileges.

## References
* Common Weakness Enumeration: [CWE-284](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/284.html)

fullDescription.text:
The application uses an anchor tag whose `target` attribute is set to `_blank`, but the `rel` attribute is not set with the `noopener` value. The page opened from that target link may have the access to the `location` object of the original page through `window.opener.location`. A malicious page associated with this link will be able to navigate the original page to an arbitrary site, such as a phishing site, and thus, execute a reverse tabnabbing attack.
Note that most contemporary browsers add the `noopener` value to the `rel` automatically by default. Thus, only users with older versions of browsers are targets for this phishing attack.

help.markdown:
## Description
The application uses an anchor tag whose `target` attribute is set to `_blank`, but the `rel` attribute is not set with the `noopener` value. The page opened from that target link may have the access to the `location` object of the original page through `window.opener.location`. A malicious page associated with this link will be able to navigate the original page to an arbitrary site, such as a phishing site, and thus, execute a reverse tabnabbing attack.
Note that most contemporary browsers add the `noopener` value to the `rel` automatically by default. Thus, only users with older versions of browsers are targets for this phishing attack.

[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/issues?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&filter=issueType%3Alocalized-name%3DInsecure%20Link%20Target%26context%3AtoolType%3Dsast)



## Remediation
To prevent untrusted pages linked from the application from being able to manipulate the "window.opener" object, set the attribute rel="noopener noreferrer" for each HTML link to external sites. In addition to preventing reverse tabnabbing attacks, it may also improve browser performance as the new page can be run in a separate process.

When the rel attribute is set to "noopener", the "window.opener" object is "null" on the new page. Therefore, the attacker cannot manipulate the navigation of the original page.  Additionally, the "noreferrer" attribute tells the browser to not include referrer information when the new page is requested.

For links opened with JavaScript, add the values "noopener", "noreferrer" as the "windowFeatures" parameter in the "window.open()" function:
```
var childWindow = window.open(url, name, "noopener,noreferrer");   
```
For legacy browser support, you can also manually set the opener to "null":
```
childWindow.opener = null;  
```

**Note**: The rel="noopener" attribute setting is supported by most modern browsers such as Firefox, Chrome, Edge and Safari but is not supported by legacy browsers such as Internet Explorer. For the latest information on browser support, refer to https://caniuse.com/#search=rel.

## References
* Common Weakness Enumeration: [CWE-1022](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/1022.html)

A malicious page associated with this link will be able to navigate the original page to an arbitrary site, such as a phishing site, and thus, execute a reverse tabnabbing attack.
Note that most contemporary browsers add the `noopener` value to the `rel` automatically by default. Thus, only users with older versions of browsers are targets for this phishing attack.

fullDescription.text: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to.

help.markdown:
## Description
A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to.

[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/issues?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&filter=issueType%3Alocalized-name%3DUse%20of%20Hard-coded%20Credentials%26context%3AtoolType%3Dsast)



## Remediation
Potential mitigations include the following:
  1. For outbound authentication: store passwords, keys, and other credentials outside of the code in a strongly-protected, encrypted configuration file or database that is protected from access by all outsiders, including other local users on the same system. Properly protect the key (CWE-320). If you cannot use encryption to protect the file, then make sure that the permissions are as restrictive as possible [REF-7].

In Windows environments, the Encrypted File System (EFS) may provide some protection.

  2. For inbound authentication: Rather than hard-code a default username and password, key, or other authentication credentials for first time logins, utilize a "first login" mode that requires the user to enter a unique strong password or key.
  3. If the software must contain hard-coded credentials or they cannot be removed, perform access control checks and limit which entities can access the feature that requires the hard-coded credentials. For example, a feature might only be enabled through the system console instead of through a network connection.
  4. For inbound authentication using passwords: apply strong one-way hashes to passwords and store those hashes in a configuration file or database with appropriate access control. That way, theft of the file/database still requires the attacker to try to crack the password. When handling an incoming password during authentication, take the hash of the password and compare it to the saved hash.

Use randomly assigned salts for each separate hash that is generated. This increases the amount of computation that an attacker needs to conduct a brute-force attack, possibly limiting the effectiveness of the rainbow table method.

  5. For front-end to back-end connections: Three solutions are possible, although none are complete.

    * The first suggestion involves the use of generated passwords or keys that are changed automatically and must be entered at given time intervals by a system administrator. These passwords will be held in memory and only be valid for the time intervals.
    * Next, the passwords or keys should be limited at the back end to only performing actions valid for the front end, as opposed to having full access.
    * Finally, the messages sent should be tagged and checksummed with time sensitive values so as to prevent replay-style attacks.

## References
* Common Weakness Enumeration: [CWE-798](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/798.html)
help.text: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to.

fullDescription.text: HTTP responses contain an `X-Powered-By` header that reveals information about the server which helps attackers exploit known vulnerabilities or craft more targeted exploits.

help.markdown:
## Description
HTTP responses contain an `X-Powered-By` header that reveals information about the server which helps attackers exploit known vulnerabilities or craft more targeted exploits.

[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/issues?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&filter=issueType%3Alocalized-name%3DInsertion%20of%20Sensitive%20Information%20Into%20Sent%20Data%26context%3AtoolType%3Dsast)



## Remediation
Potential mitigations include the following:
  1. Specify which data in the software should be regarded as sensitive. Consider which types of users should have access to which types of data.
  2. Ensure that any possibly sensitive data specified in the requirements is verified with designers to ensure that it is either a calculated risk or mitigated elsewhere. Any information that is not necessary to the functionality should be removed in order to lower both the overhead and the possibility of security sensitive data being sent.
  3. Setup default error messages so that unexpected errors do not disclose sensitive information.
  4. Compartmentalize the system to have "safe" areas where trust boundaries can be unambiguously drawn. Do not allow sensitive data to go outside of the trust boundary and always be careful when interfacing with a compartment outside of the safe area.

Ensure that appropriate compartmentalization is built into the system design, and the compartmentalization allows for and reinforces privilege separation functionality. Architects and designers should rely on the principle of least privilege to decide the appropriate time to use privileges and the time to drop privileges.

## References
* Common Weakness Enumeration: [CWE-201](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/201.html)
help.text: HTTP responses contain an `X-Powered-By` header that reveals information about the server which helps attackers exploit known vulnerabilities or craft more targeted exploits.

shortDescription.text: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output

fullDescription.text: Setting the `autoescape` attribute to `false` disables the escaping mechanism of the Swig template engine. This may lead to XSS attack if untrusted data is not properly validated and escaped.

help.markdown:
## Description
Setting the `autoescape` attribute to `false` disables the escaping mechanism of the Swig template engine. This may lead to XSS attack if untrusted data is not properly validated and escaped.

[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/issues?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&filter=issueType%3Alocalized-name%3DImproper%20Encoding%20or%20Escaping%20of%20Output%26context%3AtoolType%3Dsast)



## Remediation
Potential mitigations include the following:
  1. Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

For example, consider using the ESAPI Encoding control [REF-45] or a similar tool, library, or framework. These will help the programmer encode outputs in a manner less prone to error.

Alternately, use built-in functions, but consider using wrappers in case those functions are discovered to have a vulnerability.

  2. If available, use structured mechanisms that automatically enforce the separation between data and code. These mechanisms may be able to provide the relevant quoting, encoding, and validation automatically, instead of relying on the developer to provide this capability at every point where output is generated.

For example, stored procedures can enforce database query structure and reduce the likelihood of SQL injection.

  3. Understand the context in which your data will be used and the encoding that will be expected. This is especially important when transmitting data between different components, or when generating outputs that can contain multiple encodings at the same time, such as web pages or multi-part mail messages. Study all expected communication protocols and data representations to determine the required encoding strategies.
  4. In some cases, input validation may be an important strategy when output encoding is not a complete solution. For example, you may be providing the same output that will be processed by multiple consumers that use different encodings or representations. In other cases, you may be required to allow user-supplied input to contain control information, such as limited HTML tags that support formatting in a wiki or bulletin board. When this type of requirement must be met, use an extremely strict allowlist to limit which control sequences can be used. Verify that the resulting syntactic structure is what you expect. Use your normal encoding methods for the remainder of the input.
  5. Use input validation as a defense-in-depth measure to reduce the likelihood of output encoding errors (see CWE-20).
  6. Fully specify which encodings are required by components that will be communicating with each other.
  7. When exchanging data between components, ensure that both components are using the same character encoding. Ensure that the proper encoding is applied at each interface. Explicitly set the encoding you are using whenever the protocol allows you to do so.

help.markdown:
## Description
The Docker Compose file sets the `no-new-privileges` attribute to `false` or omits it as the default value is `false`. This doesn't restrict the container from acquiring additional privileges via SUID or SGID bits. This allows privilege escalation, meaning a user can set the security context of the container and can perform root-level operations.

[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/issues?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&filter=issueType%3Alocalized-name%3DImproper%20Privilege%20Management%26context%3AtoolType%3Dsast)



## Remediation
Potential mitigations include the following:
  1. Very carefully manage the setting, management, and handling of privileges. Explicitly manage trust zones in the software.
  2. Follow the principle of least privilege when assigning access rights to entities in a software system.
  3. Consider following the principle of separation of privilege. Require multiple conditions to be met before permitting access to a system resource.

fullDescription.text: A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to.

help.markdown:
## Description
A secret, such as a password, cryptographic key, or token is stored in plaintext directly in the source code, in an application's properties, or configuration file. Users with access to the secret may then use the secret to access resources that they otherwise would not have access to.

[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/issues?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&filter=issueType%3Alocalized-name%3DUse%20of%20Hard-coded%20Credentials%26context%3AtoolType%3Dsast)



## Remediation
Potential mitigations include the following:
  1. For outbound authentication: store passwords, keys, and other credentials outside of the code in a strongly-protected, encrypted configuration file or database that is protected from access by all outsiders, including other local users on the same system. Properly protect the key (CWE-320). If you cannot use encryption to protect the file, then make sure that the permissions are as restrictive as possible [REF-7].

In Windows environments, the Encrypted File System (EFS) may provide some protection.

  2. For inbound authentication: Rather than hard-code a default username and password, key, or other authentication credentials for first time logins, utilize a "first login" mode that requires the user to enter a unique strong password or key.
  3. If the software must contain hard-coded credentials or they cannot be removed, perform access control checks and limit which entities can access the feature that requires the hard-coded credentials. For example, a feature might only be enabled through the system console instead of through a network connection.
  4. For inbound authentication using passwords: apply strong one-way hashes to passwords and store those hashes in a configuration file or database with appropriate access control. That way, theft of the file/database still requires the attacker to try to crack the password. When handling an incoming password during authentication, take the hash of the password and compare it to the saved hash.

Use randomly assigned salts for each separate hash that is generated. This increases the amount of computation that an attacker needs to conduct a brute-force attack, possibly limiting the effectiveness of the rainbow table method.

  5. For front-end to back-end connections: Three solutions are possible, although none are complete.

    * The first suggestion involves the use of generated passwords or keys that are changed automatically and must be entered at given time intervals by a system administrator. These passwords will be held in memory and only be valid for the time intervals.
    * Next, the passwords or keys should be limited at the back end to only performing actions valid for the front end, as opposed to having full access.
    * Finally, the messages sent should be tagged and checksummed with time sensitive values so as to prevent replay-style attacks.

fullDescription.text: The configuration of the `client-sessions`, `cookie-session` or `express-session` library does not set the `secure` attribute of the session cookie. While web browsers send cookies with the `secure` attribute only over HTTPS, they do send cookies without it over HTTP. If an attacker can fool the victim's browser into sending an HTTP request to the vulnerable site (for example, with JavaScript code on a malicious page or with a phishing link), the victim's browser will send the vulnerable cookie in clear text. If the attacker can also intercept this network traffic, then they can steal the victim's session cookie and impersonate the victim.

help.markdown:
## Description
The configuration of the `client-sessions`, `cookie-session` or `express-session` library does not set the `secure` attribute of the session cookie. While web browsers send cookies with the `secure` attribute only over HTTPS, they do send cookies without it over HTTP. If an attacker can fool the victim's browser into sending an HTTP request to the vulnerable site (for example, with JavaScript code on a malicious page or with a phishing link), the victim's browser will send the vulnerable cookie in clear text. If the attacker can also intercept this network traffic, then they can steal the victim's session cookie and impersonate the victim.

[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/issues?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&filter=issueType%3Alocalized-name%3DSecure%20Cookie%20Attribute%20Not%20Set%26context%3AtoolType%3Dsast)



## Remediation
Set the 'Secure' attribute should on all cookies that contain sensitive data, especially those containing session IDs. The mitigation details depend on the application server, with some requiring programmatic configuration, where others can be configured through an administration interface. 

If not already done, consider deploying HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) headers to minimize the risk of plain-text HTTP requests to the application server.

shortDescription.text: Sensitive Cookie with Improper SameSite Attribute

fullDescription.text: The `cookie.sameSite` option is either undefined or set to the insecure value `none` or `false`. In all three cases, the cookie's `SameSite` attribute protections are disabled, allowing the browser to send cookies in cross-site requests. An attacker can abuse this missing protection to facilitate cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.

help.markdown:
## Description
The `cookie.sameSite` option is either undefined or set to the insecure value `none` or `false`. In all three cases, the cookie's `SameSite` attribute protections are disabled, allowing the browser to send cookies in cross-site requests. An attacker can abuse this missing protection to facilitate cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.

[Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://pim.altair.synopsys.com/portfolio/portfolios/fc7e733e-7956-43d0-8d0d-4aa33c4c2ef7/portfolio-items/0c21d02d-1ab1-4c0e-8cad-0a209bf54bf1/projects/7d37f559-2c8f-4c55-b5a7-9d9a7a400020/issues?branchId=7ebf5873-4c60-4f27-8d96-bc71e40659fd&filter=issueType%3Alocalized-name%3DSensitive%20Cookie%20with%20Improper%20SameSite%20Attribute%26context%3AtoolType%3Dsast)



## Remediation
The server should explicitly set the SameSite attribute for all cookies containing sensitive data, such as session tokens. This can be accomplished either programmatically when setting Set-Cookie headers in responses or via deployment descriptors provided by various frameworks.

The setting "SameSite=Strict" provides the strongest protection against CSRF but the user experience works best when an application uses two different cookies, one for write-access that is locked down with "SameSite=Strict" and another for read-access that can have a more permissive setting, e.g., "SameSite=Lax". If the application only relies on one cookie for both read & write access, then the setting "SameSite=Lax" provides some protection against CSRF without too much negative impact on user experience. 

It's worth noting that the definition of same-site is less restrictive than the definition of cross-origin, e.g., requests from other sub-domains are considered same-site although they are from a different origin. This means that even in browsers that fully support the "SameSite" cookie attribute, an attacker may still circumvent this protection if they can take over a subdomain or inject HTML or JavaScript into any subdomain of the same site. Therefore, relying on the "SameSite" attribute is not recommended as the sole defense against cross-site request forgery, it should instead be seen as a defense in depth mechanism that reduces the likelihood of CSRF.

## References
* Common Weakness Enumeration: [CWE-1275](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/1275.html)

shortDescription.text: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere

fullDescription.text: The `client-sessions`, `cookie-session` or `express-session` library sets the `path` attribute on the session cookie to the root or doesn't set `path` attribute (default value is root). If the application is hosted beneath a subdirectory and the cookie is copied to the root, then applications in other subdirectories will have access to this cookie. If any of these applications become compromised, the cookie of the victim site can be stolen from this application.

## Local Effect

The indicated dead code may have performed some action; that action will never occur.


## Remediation
Unreachable and dead code should be analyzed and either removed or corrected depending on whether it is needed. If the code should execute but doesn't, any bugs preventing the code from executing must be fixed. If the code is not needed, and its removal will not have a negative impact on the application, it should be removed.
